awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Privacy-Responsive Artificial Intelligence-Based Solution for Smart Video Surveillance
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is exploring societal needs, market prospects, and obstacles in harnessing the latest artificial intelligence breakthroughs to tackle public safety challenges. This project uncovers and adopts optimal practices to maximize the advantages of intelligent video surveillance technologies while addressing the associated privacy and ethical considerations. This project seeks to create a responsible and privacy-responsive artificial intelligence that various stakeholders, business owners, local communities, and the public can accept, adopt, and use. By using advanced technologies ethically and responsibly, this project aims to create a buffer between authorities and civilians, minimizing unnecessary conflicts and eliminating biases based on race, ethnicity, gender, age, and socioeconomic status.

This I-Corps project is based on developing artificial intelligence-based computer vision and video analytic technologies to perform complex cognitive tasks to identify potentially threatening anomalous behaviors in community spaces. Furthermore, it will equip end-users to view meta-analyses based on temporal events and statistics by providing a mobile application and a web portal to notify the residents, commuters, and responsible security personnel. The entire intelligent processing will perform next to the cameras without saving or sending the actual videos to an external server. For anomaly detection, the proposed technology will not use personally identifiable information or facial recognition and only relies on behaviors and activities within community spaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Recent years have seen a rise in threats to public safety, requiring innovative solutions to address growing concerns about criminal activity, school violence, and community security. This project explored how artificial intelligence (AI) and computer vision can transform traditional video surveillance, which often relies on inefficient human monitoring, into a scalable and effective tool for real-time threat detection and response. By using advanced algorithms, the technology can perform complex tasks such as action recognition and anomaly detection while offering statistical insights over time.

Through participation in the NSF I-Corps program, the team conducted over 500 interviews with stakeholders, including law enforcement, infrastructure security professionals, business owners, and residents. These discussions provided crucial insights into the market needs, technical requirements, and ethical considerations for deploying AI-driven surveillance systems. The feedback led to a strategic focus on infrastructure safety and security, an area where the technology can have the most immediate impact. The project resulted in the formation of Chimeras LLC, a university spinout startup that is now an active member of the Security Industry Association. With additional support through an NSF Partnerships for Innovation grant, the company is advancing its mission to deliver fair, ethical, and highly effective surveillance solutions. The team also published findings highlighting the public relevance of this technology, contributing to broader discussions on its societal implications. This work has the potential to revolutionize surveillance by making it more accurate, cost-effective, and socially responsible. By addressing privacy concerns and mitigating bias, the project paves the way for ethical AI applications in public safety, fostering trust and equity.
